metadata.synopsis: While his wife, Kim (Regina King), brings home the bacon, unemployed Charlie (Eddie Murphy) spends his days caring for the couple's young son. With help from a friend, Phil (Jeff Garlin), Charlie decides to start a day care center. Enrollment quickly surges, and, as they add another employee, goofy Marvin (Steve Zahn), Charlie finds himself dealing with endless red tape. Will he be able to keep the business afloat, or will parents defect to Mrs. Harridan's (Anjelica Huston) day care center?

reviews: There's almost no role I prefer Zahn in than one involving children.
Steve Zahn and Huston apart, this is erosive candy for the Murphy die-hard.
It makes Kindergarten Cop and Bringing Up Baby sparkle in comparison.
Even allowing for genre limitations, this is a very bad movie indeed.
the appeal of the movie doesn't go much farther than the concept
These scenes are so inevitable, you could develop a drinking game around them.
Eddie Murphy in slapstick potty humor comedy.
Maybe it's about time Murphy fired his agent and tried reviving his career.
My advice is to beat your children rather than take them to Daddy Day Care.
Daddy Day Care just wants to make you laugh, and make your kids laugh too.
Someone needs a time-out to think about writing a better script.
It moves with such turgid lack of energy that I found myself wincing, trying to smooth over the rhythm with my imagination.
The kiddies will love every formulaic moment. Heck, they probably won't even care that quality thespian Angelica Huston is reduced to an embarrassing wreck.
Daddy Day Care is a manufactured film which is willing to capitalize on the fact that a sucker of a filmgoer is born every minute.
Eddie Murphy has kept his swelled ego in check here, but being too naughty when it should be nice stings the movie.
